author: By Lauren Christensen
title: ‘You Will Stay Silent’: Photographs From Behind the Iron Curtain
description: Images taken in the 1970s and ’80s provide a glimpse into life under autocracy.
content: In 1977, the photojournalist Arthur Grace arrived at Berlin’s Tempelhof Airport to document “life behind the Iron Curtain” for Time and Newsweek. Taken over 12 years, the black-and-white images collected in COMMUNISM(S): A COLD WAR ALBUM (Damiani, $60) reflect just that: the everyday lives of citizens young and old, rich and poor, proud and powerless, set against the literally colorless backdrops of Poland, the Soviet Union, Romania, East Germany and Yugoslavia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: I’m on a Monthly Lease. Can My Landlord Suddenly Evict Me and My Dog?
description: Renting on a month-to-month basis can leave tenants in a vulnerable position. But landlords often want to make a deal rather than evict.
content: Q: My wife and I have rented an apartment in a three-family house in Queens, N.Y., for the past decade. Whenever our son is on rotation in the U.S. military, we dog sit his golden retriever. Our original lease gave us permission to do this, but it expired years ago and we’ve been on a month-to-month agreement ever since. We are now dog sitting again. The other day, the landlord told me that the building allowed dogs only under 20 pounds, even though our original lease did not include weight restrictions. (Other tenants in the building have dogs, though theirs are smaller than ours.) The landlord then told me that we could move out at any time. Can he really evict us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Fill your cultural calendar with Pulitzer winners, piano bars and 24 ways to make eggs.
content: When “Fat Ham,” James Ijames’s adaptation of “Hamlet” set in the American South, debuted last year as a streaming-only production from Philadelphia’s Wilma Theater, my colleague Jesse Green lauded it as “the rare takeoff that actually takes off.” This week, “Fat Ham” won the Pulitzer Prize for drama and began in-person performances at New York’s Public Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Sullivan
title: A Medical History of Transplant Surgery That’s Not for the Squeamish
description: Paul Craddock’s gory and engrossing “Spare Parts” takes on ancient skin grafts, modern plastic surgery and everything in between.
content: SPARE PARTSThe Story of Medicine Through the History of Transplant SurgeryBy Paul Craddock
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Jacinda Ardern, whose restrictions buffered New Zealand from the worst of the pandemic, tests positive.
description: The prime minister’s rules kept transmission at bay for two years, and by the time the highly infectious Omicron variant hit, the vast majority of New Zealand’s population had been vaccinated.
content: Jacinda Ardern, the prime minister of New Zealand who led the island nation through the pandemic, has tested positive for the coronavirus, her office said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: From Streets to Rallies, Truckers and Supporters Weigh Conservative Candidates
description: In his bid for the Conservative Party leadership Pierre Poilievre is wooing supporters of the blockade that shut down Ottawa and closed border points.
content: To the relief of many in Ottawa, the large crowds expected to descend on the city this weekend will be admiring tulips rather than blocking streets, honking truck horns and protesting pandemic restrictions and vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Skandha Gunasekara
title: A Ruling Family on the Run as Sri Lanka Plunges Into Economic Ruin
description: Once empowered by triumphant ethnic nationalism after a brutal civil war, the Rajapaksa dynasty has been undone by what its own allies call incompetence and denial.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — As the guests sat down for a banquet dinner last summer at the grand colonial-era home of Sri Lanka’s president, the small talk soon turned gravely serious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Way Out West
description: Daniel Mauer gives us a lift.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is Daniel Mauer’s first Sunday puzzle after four themed daily grids. Mr. Mauer is a software engineer in Massachusetts who started solving puzzles with his father while growing up. He first took a crack at construction about six years ago. Now, he and his wife enjoy solving the Times puzzle every morning, as well as going on road trips, a perfect combination for today’s puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Alabama’s Transgender Youth Can Use Medicine to Transition, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge temporarily halted part of a new law that prevents doctors from prescribing puberty blockers and hormone therapies to transgender youth. He upheld a ban on sex-altering operations.
content: A federal judge late Friday blocked portions of an Alabama law that prevent medical professionals from providing care that helps transgender children and teenagers transition, making it a felony offense that is punishable by up to 10 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Push to Silence Protesters Over the Roe Decision
description: Gathering near the homes of public officials is not a new trend.
content: In the two weeks since an anonymous source leaked Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade, there have been several protests against conservative Supreme Court justices at their homes. One took place in front of the home of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, one in front of the home of Chief Justice John Roberts and one in front of the home of Alito himself. None of the protests were rowdy or disruptive. There were no threats and no one was in danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar
title: Building Fire in India’s Capital Leaves Dozens Dead
description: Officials said that at least 27 people had been killed, most of them assembly line workers, and that the toll could rise.
content: NEW DELHI — Rescuers were searching for victims on Saturday in the ruins of a New Delhi commercial building that was gutted by fire the night before, leaving at least 27 people dead. Officials warned that the toll could rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Mohammed bin Zayed, an Ambitious U.S. Partner, Rises to Lead the U.A.E.
description: Sheikh Mohammed has used his small country’s oil wealth to exert great influence across the Middle East and in Washington.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan became the president of the United Arab Emirates on Saturday, formalizing the rise of a 61-year-old prince who has deftly wielded his country’s oil wealth to become one of the most influential leaders in the Arab world and a close partner of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Teresa Berganza, Charismatic Star of the Opera Stage, Is Dead at 89
description: The Spanish mezzo-soprano was internationally acclaimed for her dramatic performances in the works of Mozart, Rossini and Bizet.
content: Teresa Berganza, a Spanish mezzo-soprano and contralto renowned for her roles in the operas of Rossini and Mozart and especially for the title role in Bizet’s “Carmen,” died on Friday in Madrid. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Andrew Testa
title: In London, a Long-Awaited High-Tech Train Is Ready to Roll
description: The Elizabeth line, 13 years in the making, will soon uncoil under central London with cathedral-like stations and roomy cars. Its managers say it’s a testament to the power of public transportation.
content: LONDON — When Andy Byford ran New York City’s dilapidated subway system, fed-up New Yorkers hailed his crusade to make the trains run with fewer delays and lamented his premature exit after clashes with the governor at the time, Andrew M. Cuomo. He was a familiar, unfailingly cheerful presence on its often-restive platforms. Straphangers even took to calling him “Train Daddy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Jenkins
title: We Can’t Drill Our Way to Energy Security
description: Investing in clean energy, efficiency and electrification is the only path to get us there.
content: Thanks to a remarkable oil and gas boom, the United States has achieved the long-sought goal of energy self-sufficiency: We now produce more oil and refined products, natural gas and coal than we consume. In particular, horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing — fracking — transformed the United States from the world’s largest oil importer to a net exporter of both oil and gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Natalie Kitroeff
title: For Putin, a Nordic Nightmare Is Springing to Life
description: With Finland and Sweden likely to request NATO membership, and Ukraine counterattacking in the east, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is facing more setbacks.
content: For years, President Vladimir V. Putin has viewed the expansion of NATO as an existential threat that would leave Russia hemmed in with Western missiles on its doorstep. Now, Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine seems to be bringing the Russian leader’s nightmare to life, with NATO on the brink of starting its largest potential expansion in nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: An Outsider Takes an Inside Look at the Oxford ‘Chums’ Who Run the U.K.
description: Simon Kuper has written a book that captures Boris Johnson and other future Conservative politicians when they were ambitious and misbehaving undergrads, planning their rise to power.
content: LONDON — Soon after Simon Kuper began his first year of studies at Oxford University in 1988 he noticed an undergraduate who was always carrying an umbrella, wearing a dark double-breasted suit and old-school spectacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Raichlen
title: How to Grill the Perfect Steak
description: Reverse-seared tri-tip may be the tastiest dish you grill all summer. Steven Raichlen guides you through the process.
content: The quest to cook the perfect steak has been a challenge since slabs of meat were roasted over fire. But what constitutes a great steak?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Ed Shanahan
title: Police Fatally Shoot a Man in the Bronx, Officials Say
description: The death came just days after officers in the borough killed a 25-year-old man who officials said had fired first during a chase.
content: Police officers in the Bronx killed a man they said had fired at them with an air pistol on Friday night, the second such fatal encounter in the borough in four days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Another Unequal Burden’: Working with Long Covid
description: Some research has shown that lingering Covid symptoms are more prevalent in people in their 30s and 40s — when workers are often in the prime of their careers. How will companies support employees with debilitating symptoms that can linger for months or even years after infection?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo, Alex Marshall, Dan Bilefsky and Anushka Patil
title: Ukraine wins the Eurovision Song Contest.
description: The country’s entry, the folk rap band Kalush Orchestra, triumphed thanks to the popular vote.
content: TURIN, Italy — The Ukrainian rap and folk band Kalush Orchestra won the Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday, as European viewers and juries delivered a symbolic, pop culture endorsement of solidarity behind Ukraine in its defense against Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Tramuta
title: Beyond the Châteaux: New Escapes in France’s Loire Valley
description: Rethinking what the region’s travel should be has meant expanding the focus from fairy tale castle crawls to experiences anchored more firmly in nature, food and the arts.
content: On my last prepandemic trip to the Loire Valley, in 2018, I found myself in a familiar place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Carrie White, Hair Stylist to the Stars, Is Dead at 78
description: Her Beverly Hills salon was a party scene where she roller-skated among her glamorous clientele, including Elizabeth Taylor and Warren Beatty.
content: When she graduated from Hollywood High School in 1961, Carrie White did her hair up in a bubblegum-pink beehive. She had learned, she wrote in her memoir, that “if I could get my hair right, my life would work better.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Simmons, Amanda Holpuch and Sophie Kasakove
title: At Least 17 Wounded in Downtown Milwaukee Shooting, Police Say
description: No fatalities were reported in the shooting on Friday night, which happened blocks from the arena where an N.B.A. playoff game ended hours earlier.
content: MILWAUKEE — At least 17 people were wounded in a shooting in downtown Milwaukee on Friday night, blocks from the arena where an N.B.A. playoff game ended hours earlier, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Lola Fadulu
title: With Roe in Peril, Thousands Gather at Marches for Abortion Rights
description: Nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, protesters gathered in Washington, New York and other cities.
content: WASHINGTON — In the nation’s capital, protesters marched to the Supreme Court in the rain while chanting “We will not go back” and “Abortion is a human right.” In New York, thousands crossed the Brooklyn Bridge. And in Los Angeles, demonstrators filled a park near City Hall to show their support for abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Student Debt Is Crushing. Canceling It for Everyone Is Still a Bad Idea.
description: Debt forgiveness won’t fix what’s wrong with higher education.
content: The astronomical level of student debt accrued in the United States is inflicting lasting, generational damage on the lives of millions of Americans. More than 45 million people are now carrying more than $1.7 trillion in debt, most of it owed to the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Laetitia Vancon
title: At a German Hideaway, Oligarch Villas Challenge a ‘Silent Contract’
description: Tegernsee, a luxury getaway in Bavaria, is known for quietly hosting the superrich. But war in Ukraine has divided locals about whether the authorities should go after the assets of their wealthy Russian neighbors.
content: ROTTACH-EGERN, Germany — Nestled among snow-capped mountains an hour’s drive south of Munich, the villages around the Alpine lake of Tegernsee have been a playground of the superrich for centuries — whether Bavarian kings, Russian czars, Nazi elites or pop stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How Do Higher Interest Rates Bring Down Inflation?
description: Our columnist is responding to readers’ questions. This week, he focuses on inflation, with the help of a bond maven and a Nobel laureate.
content: It’s nasty out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Lil Keed, Up-and-Coming Atlanta Rapper, Dies at 24
description: The musician, a protégé of Young Thug, died on Friday in Los Angeles, his label said.
content: Lil Keed, a budding, melodic rapper from Atlanta with a delicate voice that he often stretched into a helium-high, Auto-Tuned falsetto, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Anushka Patil
title: Amid war and destruction, Ukraine is favored to win the wildly popular Eurovision Song Contest.
description: The exclusion of Russia from the contest has underlined the country’s estrangement from the west, including in popular culture.
content: For 11 weeks, Ukrainians have been braving war, destruction and loss. But on Saturday, they could be celebrating victory: The country’s rousing, hip-hop infused song “Stefania” is favored to win the Eurovision Song Contest, the cultural phenomenon that helped launch Abba and Celine Dion and is watched annually by 200 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says Its Covid Outbreak Is Spreading Fast
description: State media reported 21 new deaths and a huge jump in suspected cases on Saturday, but it was unclear how many had been definitively linked to the coronavirus.
content: SEOUL — North Korea reported a significant surge in suspected coronavirus infections and deaths on Saturday as it struggled to contain its first reported outbreak, which the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said could be one of the greatest crises in the country’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Jayson Tatum Had the Game of His Life to Save the Celtics’ Season
description: Was it the 46 points? The crushing 3-pointers? The clutch free throws? Tatum, the Boston forward, was feeling it against the Milwaukee Bucks on Friday.
content: There was a time when the Boston Celtics’ season seemed in danger of crumbling into a pile of fine dust. They had a losing record in late January. They were scuffling through a series of injuries. There were questions about whether Jayson Tatum could coexist with Jaylen Brown — was it time for the team to consider trading Brown? — along with inevitable critiques of Ime Udoka in his first season as coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Stand for Something
description: Get wrapped up in Ada Nicolle’s edifying Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This effervescent construction is Ada Nicolle’s first Saturday puzzle and third daily Times Crossword overall. All nine debuts, as well as many other entries, really popped off the page to me in a joyful way when I got them. Cluing is tough but fair and clever, and the sticky spots either solve to something deducible or come with an accessible set of crossing entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Valeriya Safronova
title: Crypto Joins the Abortion Conversation
description: Activists and nonprofits are considering digital currencies as a way to raise funds. But can they really do anything other payment methods can’t?
content: In the loud and confusing world of cryptocurrencies, fund-raising efforts are forming around all sorts of causes. Groups known as decentralized autonomous organizations, or DAOs, have sent aid to Ukrainians whose lives have been upended by war, worked to offset carbon emissions, bought land and collected NFTs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Raichlen
title: How to Set Up Your Grill for Reverse Searing
description: Smoking a steak over low heat before finishing it over a hot fire ensures even cooking. Here’s how to get the grill ready for the technique.
content: Reverse-searing can be done on a charcoal or gas grill, but it’s easier to smoke with charcoal. The method requires little more in the way of special equipment than a grill with a lid and an accurate meat thermometer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Quit Telling Me to Conquer My Fear
description: If I do the thing I’m terrified of, I don’t see how that’s a great accomplishment.
content: Like many people, I have a number of fears. I am not a big fan of climbing mountains (too high!) or the idea of swimming in deep ocean waters (too low!). And sometimes I feel as if my fears — rational as they may seem in my head — make me less of an adult, less capable, less fully realized as a human being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: An American Moment in an Australian Campaign
description: To some analysts, a spat over transition surgery looks like something from an overseas culture war.
content: Perhaps the ugliest part of Australia’s election campaign has been the debate around the rights of transgender people. Katherine Deves, Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s handpicked candidate for the seat of Warringah, courted controversy this week when she walked back a previous apology for calling transition surgery “mutilation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Catalan Pop? Corsican Rock? It’s Europe’s Other Song Contest.
description: The Liet International, a competition for minority and regional languages, lacks the glitz of Eurovision. But its organizers say it helps keep endangered tongues alive.
content: Follow live updates on the Eurovision grand final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: 4 Who Helped Catch Subway Attack Suspect Now Need Help Themselves
description: They aided investigators after the worst subway attack in decades. Will that be enough to persuade immigration authorities to give them visas or asylum?
content: After New York’s worst subway attack in decades, a Mexican woman who had been on the ill-fated train gave police her cellphone to retrieve videos of the chaos. She was undocumented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: The gunman broadcast the attack on a livestreaming site.
description: Twitch, the livestreaming site owned by Amazon that is popular with gamers, said it had taken the channel offline.
content: Officials said the gunman broadcast the attack live on Twitch, the livestreaming site owned by Amazon that is popular with gamers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson, Jenny Vrentas and Kevin Draper
title: The Disarray and ‘Stone Age’ Dysfunction of the Las Vegas Raiders
description: Former employees described an N.F.L. franchise bedeviled by executive departures, poor financial management, unpaid electric bills and a raft of firings, payouts and N.D.A.s.
content: The Las Vegas Raiders have been rocked by a mass exodus of front office leaders amid financial irregularities and dire management blunders like overpaying taxes and underpaying certain employees for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Victoria Kim
title: India bans most wheat exports, adding to concerns of global food insecurity.
description: The ban could compound a worldwide shortfall worsened by the war in Ukraine and exacerbate an already dire forecast for global hunger.
content: India, the world’s second-largest wheat producer, has banned exports of the grain with some exceptions, a move that could compound a worldwide shortfall worsened by the war in Ukraine and exacerbate an already dire forecast for hunger across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Trump Backs Doug Mastriano, a Far-Right Loyalist, to Lead Pennsylvania
description: Mr. Mastriano, who has promoted many false claims of a stolen 2020 election, was the leading Republican candidate for governor even before Donald Trump’s endorsement.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday endorsed Doug Mastriano, a retired colonel and state senator who has propagated myriad false claims about the 2020 election and attended the protest leading up to the Capitol riot, in the Republican primary race for governor of Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: What Would a Feminist Jail Look Like?
description: Women inmates are less dangerous than incarcerated men. Their prisons should reflect that reality.
content: One Saturday morning in 1992, as she was coming home from a night shift as a home health aide, Sharon White got off the subway a few stops early at Gun Hill Road in the Bronx, hoping to find a bathroom. At the station, she ran into a high-school friend, Judy, whom she had not seen in a long time and who offered to take her to the apartment of a man she was dating. It wasn’t far away, and she could use the bathroom at his place. Ms. White took her up on the offer and left the apartment after a few minutes. Sometime later, she realized that her purse was missing, so the next morning she went back to the apartment in hopes of retrieving it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pelosi Promises ‘Urgent Action’ in House to Address a Shortage of Baby Formula
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 14, 2022.
content: “The babies are crying and the babies are hungry. So we must take urgent action to protect their health and well-being.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Hottest Ticket in Town? Taylor Swift, Class of ’22.
description: New York University graduates will be rewarded with a commencement speech from the pop star, who is being awarded an honorary degree.
content: Both Jenny Dhoumo and Lauren Kirshenbaum found out on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Stephens-Davidowitz
title: The Rich Are Not Who We Think They Are. And Happiness Is Not What We Think It Is, Either.
description: There is still a lot we can learn from big data.
content: We now know who is rich in America. And it’s not who you might have guessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Too Much Church in the State
description: What’s God got to do with it?
content: WASHINGTON — During her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Amy Coney Barrett tried to reassure Democrats who were leery of her role as a “handmaid” in a Christian group called “People of Praise.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: There Are Two Endgames in Ukraine. Both Carry Big Risks.
description: Is there a third option looming for the next six months of war in Ukraine?
content: Last week brought a little clarity to the fog of the Ukraine war: The significant date of May 9, the celebration of the Soviet Union’s victory over Hitler’s Germany, came and went with no change of Russian strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey Offers to Evacuate Mariupol Fighters Despite Disagreements
description: Turkey has had a ship waiting for weeks in Istanbul to evacuate those remaining in the Azovstal steel plant, but Ukraine and Russia have not agreed to a plan, a Turkish official said.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Turkey is working to negotiate an exit for the wounded Ukrainian soldiers sheltering in the bunkers of a steel plant in the port city of Mariupol, but its efforts have been complicated by the fluidity of the fighting on the ground and because neither Russia nor Ukraine has given clearance for the plan, Turkey’s presidential spokesman said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: The Trigger That Makes an Octopus Mom Self-Destruct
description: Researchers are gaining a better understanding of the biochemical processes that precede female octopuses’ deaths after they lay and then tend their eggs.
content: Most octopus species live for one year. But the deaths of octopus mothers after they reproduce have long been a scientific spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Thomas Says Leaked Opinion Destroyed Trust at the Supreme Court
description: In remarks at a conference in Dallas, he also denounced the recent protests at justices’ homes and said conservatives would not adopt such tactics.
content: WASHINGTON — The leak of a draft opinion has done irreparable damage to the Supreme Court, Justice Clarence Thomas said at a conference in Dallas on Friday night, adding that it had destroyed trust among its members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Protests Triggered by Rising Food Prices Spread in Iran
description: “They have no hope, they have no trust in the government and they can’t tolerate the status quo any more,” one Iran expert said of the protesters in at least six provinces.
content: Protests against the government spread to at least six provinces in Iran on Friday following several days of sporadic unrest sparked by rising food prices, according to witnesses and videos posted on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: ‘We Lost Our Miracle Baby,’ Britney Spears Shares
description: The pop singer, recently released from a conservatorship that had prevented her from becoming pregnant, revealed on Instagram that she has had a miscarriage.
content: A month after announcing on Instagram that she was pregnant, the pop star Britney Spears has posted an update saying that she suffered a miscarriage, writing: “We have lost our miracle baby.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jack Cakebread, Pioneering Napa Valley Winemaker, Dies at 92
description: He was an auto mechanic with a sideline in photography when he and his wife bought a cattle farm in 1972. They turned it into one of America’s leading wineries.
content: Jack Cakebread, who with his wife, Dolores, turned a 22-acre cattle ranch in Rutherford, Calif., into one of Napa Valley’s leading wineries, along the way helping to propel the once-obscure region to global viticultural stardom, died on April 26 in Napa. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 9, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: How ‘Just a Dude’ in Shorts Became a Senate Front-Runner
description: John Fetterman has used his shorts-and-hoodie image to connect with Pennsylvania voters in the Democratic Senate primary.
content: YORK, Pa. — John Fetterman’s latest ad boasts that his campaign has become a movement. Days before Pennsylvania’s primary on Tuesday, Mr. Fetterman is the front-runner for the state’s Democratic Senate nomination. But he insists that he is simply “doing my thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: McConnell and other Republican senators make a secret visit to Ukraine.
description: The visit by the Senate minority leader included a meeting with the Ukrainian president in Kyiv.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader, visited Ukraine on Saturday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky, leading the latest delegation of American lawmakers to the country as the United States deepens its commitment to Kyiv’s fight against the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Cochrane and Rachel Woolf
title: At the Top of His Sport, Mountain Runner Focuses on the Next Generation
description: Joseph Gray is the most decorated American mountain runner. As the lone Black runner at the top, he wants to help diversify the field.
content: With 20 national championships across six disciplines and nine international gold medals, Joseph Gray is the most decorated American mountain runner, by a wide margin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: A Crypto Emperor’s Vision: No Pants, His Rules
description: Sam Bankman-Fried is a studiously disheveled billionaire who made a fortune overseeing trades that are too risky for the U.S. market. Now he wants Washington to follow his lead.
content: NASSAU, The Bahamas — The crypto executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who rose to fame by building a $40 billion business in less than three years, stood in the wings at the Baha Mar convention center, wearing his usual schlubby ensemble of shorts and a T-shirt. He was about to take the stage with Anthony Scaramucci, a former White House communications director who rose to fame by losing that job in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Beach Houses on the Outer Banks Are Being Swallowed by the Sea
description: A neighborhood of vacation homes off the coast of North Carolina has become a symbol of the effects of rising oceans.
content: RODANTHE, N.C. — Like millions of other people this week, Hien Pham marveled at the online video of the two-story, pea-green beach house as it collapsed into a rising sea, left to bob in the agitated surf like a giant cork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: The Lost Americans
description: Nearly one million people have died from Covid in the United States. Many of the loved ones they left behind are grieving in a nation that wants to move on.
content: A widow in North Carolina whose husband died of Covid-19 feels crushed when she hears people talk casually about life in America returning to normal. I will never go back to normal, she thinks to herself. I still feel as though I am missing a limb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri
title: To Survive, Some Afghans Sift Through Deadly Remnants of Old Wars
description: Discarded metal left by decades of conflict has become a livelihood for impoverished Afghans. But many have been killed by unexploded munitions.
content: TANGI VALLEY, Afghanistan — The father of six knew that where he was digging could kill him. But winter was approaching, and selling a few pounds of scrap metal peeled from a nearby abandoned military outpost could offset the rising prices of food and fuel as Afghanistan’s economy collapsed around him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Rangers Push the Penguins to Game 7 in New York
description: Linemates Chris Kreider and Mika Zibanejad each scored two goals to extend the series and guarantee New York its first Game 7 since 2015.
content: PITTSBURGH — Sitting on the bench after he had hit the crossbar with a shot on a breakaway, Mika Zibanejad asked to see a video replay so he could assess whether he made the right move against the goalie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Gearing Up for G.O.P. Gains, White House Braces for Barrage of Inquiries
description: The turbulent aftermath of the Trump era is taking the possibility of a divided government to new levels of intensity, as some Republicans appear eager to target President Biden and his family.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s legal team is laying the groundwork to defend against an expected onslaught of oversight investigations by congressional Republicans, should they take one or both chambers in the midterm elections — including preparing for the possibility of impeachment as payback for the two impeachments of President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy White, Amy Harmon, Danielle Ivory, Lauren Leatherby, Albert Sun and Sarah Almukhtar
title: How America Lost One Million People
description: Understanding the death toll — who makes up the one million and how the country failed them — is essential as the pandemic continues.
content: Understanding the death toll — who makes up the one million and how the country failed them — is essential as the pandemic continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li and Christina Kelso
title: Abortion Rights Supporters March in New York City
description: Thousands of people gathered in New York City and across the country to show their support for abortion rights nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade.
content: Thousands of people gathered in New York City and across the country to show their support for abortion rights nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 14, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 14, 2022.
content: A picture caption with an article on Friday about a crackdown on gang violence in El Salvador that led to the imprisonment of more than 25,000 people misidentified the woman shown with Irvin Antonio Hernández and his girlfriend after he was arrested. She is his sister, not his mother.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A New Generation of Powerless Women’: On Life Before Roe, and Fears for the Future
description: Readers, including those who had abortions, an “unwanted fetus” and an obstetrician, recall how girls and women dealt with unplanned pregnancies pre-Roe.
content: This is the first in a two-part series of personal stories from readers.
source.name: The New York Times
